page.title: 03SHALE BINGS
page.content: Our Heritage from the Scottish Oil Industry is a landscape filled with man-made mountains. These{Bings}(from the Gaelic 'beinn'-a mountain) are shale waste, pink, silent reminders of a once booming industry. The waste material is now put to many uses, mainly as foundation for roads such as the M8 and the Livingston dual carriageway. The shale refuse is also used in land reclamation schemes notably the one operated by B.P.'s oil refinery at Grangemouth. The refuse is also used for the making of bricks. Many bings have been reduced but enough still remain to remind us of Paraffin Young's magnificent achievements in the pioneering era of the oil business.
